On tap at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo. Pours almost pitch black with a small beige head. Strong malty aroma, some smoke and tar as well. Taste is dominated by the roasted malts, moderate hoppy bitterness and a nice dry end. Smooth mouthfeel. Good beer.

Appearance: Pitch-black colored with a huge dark brown head.

Aroma: Intense citrusy, resinous hop character with a subtle dark malty hint.

Flavor: Dry citrusy, flowery hop oils flows through with a roasted cocoa bean-like accompaniment.

Mouthfeel/Palate: Medium to full bodied with a smooth, viscous texture.

Overall: Strongly hopped, mouth-drying brew, as expected with less rich dark malt profile as a Imperial stout has. Worthy piece.

Location: 500 ml bottle from Buy Rite - Jersey City, 9/12/10


Aroma: The nose has roasted malts, chocolate, earthy notes, nutty notes, and a bit of fruity hops

Appearance: A dark brown-black pour with a creamy light brown head and good lace on the glass

Flavor: The taste starts off roasty/malty, but the bitter hoppiness takes over quickly and lasts nicely

Palate: This beer has a slightly creamy feel, is medium-full bodied, and has a nice, long duration

Overall Impression: 
This is a pretty interesting beer.  You can definitely taste the roasted/chocolate malts, but the hops are the stronger aspect of this one.  In each sip the malts are present early, but the middle and end palates are completely dominated by a strong hoppy presence.  It really works in this beer, and this is really good stuff.

Bottle. Black pour with a big brown, creamy head. Visual resemblance to Mikkellers Beer Geek Brunch. Aroma is big on roast and coffee, liquorice, spices and a large hop-profile. Also some nuts and a lovely chocolate finish. Taste is big on the roast and chocolate with some creamy vanilla-notes as well. A fairly big hop-profile in the finish. Generally sweet, but with a strong hop-bitterness as well. Medium carbonation, big body, long duration, slightly oily.

330ml draught at Håndverkerstuene. Shinny dark surface to a near-black body with ruby shades. Dark spiced fruits and malts to the nose. Loaded with dark, and half-dried fruits like raisin and plums in flavour with the support of sweet dark malts and bitter liquorice. Pleasant dry bitter ending. Good drinking (Oslo, 31.08.2010).

On tap at Haandverkerstuene.
Bitter herbal nose, think Underberg bitter.
Bittersweet flavour, very full mouth feel, oaky aftertaste.
Smoke, liquorice, a hint of salt. Resin.

(bottle, courtesy of Beerandblues2, sampled 4/10/10). Black color. Medium tan head. Sweet roasted malt aroma, with moderate hoppiness. Roasted malt flavor, with moderate hops and light smokiness. Long duration. Moderate bitter finish. Thin/slick texture. Soft carbonation. Fair lacing.

Hardly any head. Opaque black body. Roasty chocolatey strawy aroma with bready rye and grain notes. Dry-sweetish mealy roasty burnt rye taste with grainy chocolate notes. Fullish body. Soft mealy mouthfeel. Dry burnt sooty rye aftertaste with chocolatey oily notes. Light acidity as well. Lovely, and dangerously drinkable. Cant say I noticed the hops much, tough. (0.33l draft at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.)

(500 ml bottle @ Gastropub Nordic, brygget 01/28/2009)
Pours a pitch black colour with a thick light brown, coffee-like head. Awesome aroma with notes of soft and aged hops, roasted coffee and nuts. Loads of hops on the taste with notes of grapefruit and dark chocolate. Alcohol is well hidden here. The palate is oily, salty, slick and non-carbonated. Dry and long finish. This bottle is quite aged already and it would be interesting to taste a fresh version of this. Awesome beer.

50cl bottle: Oh my, what a great beer. Looks badass, dense tan-coloured head on top of an opaque body. In the aroma, the spicy, woody, very slightly citrussy hops mingle perfectly with the chocolate and coffee notes from the dark roasted grains, as well as some raisiny notes. Not muddled at all. The flavour shows some acidity, an intense, dry cocoa-like roastiness and citrussy hops. What I find exceptional about this beer is that it has a full and silky mouthfeel and still finishes dry. Highly recommended!

Tap@Håndverkerstuene. Black with brown highlights and a thin brown head. Loads of citric hops on the nose, along with burnt malts, herbal notes, almost weed like. Maybe thats just the burnt malt and citric hops combo. A milk chocolate like sweetness, some alcohol, and juicy fruitiness. Its pretty intensely roasted on the tongue, loads of citrus. Loads of bitterness in general really, but its got a sturdy sweetness to keep the hops in check. Well balanced. Mouthfeel is soft, mellow carbonation, medium bodied. This drinks like an extremely well hopped porter or stout, but the balance is just right. Liked it a lot.
A very nice roasty ops. Great blk color with a solid head. Roasted caramel malt aroma with nice roast. Chocolate malt roast spice hops. Yum.

Poured untransparent black, like a hard stout(this beer disfigure many of the best stouts...) with foamy brown head that melts down to a small lacing one. Complex aroma comes from a strong malty backgrond. Roasted malt, resiny and citrussy hop rotate in the nose. This fight between the roasted and the hoppy side goes in the flavor too.Roasted grains and citrussy hops, resin and fruits like grapfruit and grape. In the end the hoppy character dominates the aftertaste with their own fruity-resiny character. Nice, verynice!

Átláthatatlan fekete, tetején egy sötétbarna színű krémes, tömött habbal, mely ujjnyi vastagon megmarad.
Illata erőteljesen gyümölcsös, virágos, enyhén pörkölt aláfestéssel.
Picit csípősen, utána lágyan, bársonyosan indul, íze grépfrútos, narancsos.
A közepső részben (keserű) csokoládés, pörkölt, citrusos és virágos hatások érezhetők.
Befejezése eleinte virágos, enyhén fűszeres, utána válik fokozatosan egyre keserűbbé, csokoládésabbá, melyek egy pörkölt utóízben maradnak meg.
Az alkohol jól el van rejtve, testes, sűrű és komplex ez a főzet, mely összeségében igen-igen meggyőzőnek bizonyult számomra.

Bottle shared with my son, Fata2683, poured a dark brown, almost black body with tan head.  Woody aroma of pine and cedar with some hops.  Flavors of roasted malts, tobacco leaf, and light smoke with a piney hop finish.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2010 The beer pours a black color with a tan head. The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate malt, smoke, tobacco and piney hops. The flavor is roasted malt, chocolate and smoke, with a touch of piney hops to balance out the flavor. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. One of the best Black IPAs I have tried.
bottle at home ... deep black ... thin tan head ... sweet roast ... light lime hop nose ... dark roast ... little licorice ... big big hop ... well made... but i just dont like hoppy stouts.

Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and light pine. Flavors of bitter coffee and light pine, roasted malt and a bit of chocolate as well, coffee really seems to stand out as it warms. Medium-thick body, bitter and roasty with a long bitter/smokey finish. Pretty good.

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured very dark brown, with a brown lacing head. Hoppy citrus, honey blends with coffee dark chocolate and plenty of roasted malts. Medium dense with not so much carbonation, and a dry, roasted finish. A very interesting beer!

bottle pours thick black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is all hops, piny, earthy, very skunky and pungent.  Flavor is rich roasted malts, some tobacco and thin smoke with a nice pine and grapefruit hop finish.

Unlabeled bottle from the lairs of Ølkonsortiet. Opaque black pour with a really nice and medium large brown head. Looks like a nice imperial stout. The aroma has a nice amount of hard roasted malts with loads of delicious semi-dark chocolate, coffee, liquorice, nice dark caramel sweetness, almost sirupy (not overwhelming, more like a foundation for the roast and hops) and a nice amount of grassy, earthy hops. I really love the smell of this one. It smells like a really good imperial stout. Lastly, the taste is high roasted, not a lot of coffee and chocolate, but just roasted. There is some nice malt sweetness as well and a ton of bittering hops blending in with the roast and sweetness. It taste like a thing inbetween a good, strong stout and a light imperial stout. Calling this a black IPA or CDA is imo a bit of a misplacement. I think it belongs in either stout or imperial stout. But nonetheless, this is a really stellar beer whatever you call it.

Bottle (from Koelschtrinker - thanks a ton).  Strong molasses malt and pine/orange peel hops aroma.  Pours thick - oily black with giant brown head.  Sweet molasses/chocolate malt and moderately bitter orange/pine hops flavor.  Full bodied and well blended.  Nice blending of strong malt and hops flavor.   Unique - really like this one.

pours with a nice head of about 3 fingers.... wait for head to die while sniffing...

Smell is very roasty.  Roasted dark malt, not much hop on the nose.

taste is also very roasty with little to no hop presence.  Roasted Barley is there for sure, along with smoke, but has a bit of a burnt taste, almost like ashes.  No typical stout coffe or chocolate here... simple burnt barley.  I am not sure if this is supposed to be a CDA or a stout.  Bottle says Hoppy Black Ale.  Style on BA says American Stout.  RB says it is a Black IPA (CDA) I am going to review this as a stout like BA says, simply because I started and typed it there first.

mouthfeel is a little underwhelming.  reviewing this as a stout, I want this to be a bit thicker for me.  nice carbonation, nice mouthfeel, but it just screams to be thicker.

nice drinkability, but there definitely better stouts out there, especially for the price.  I wouldnt waste my money on it again.
Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells of chocolate, some coffee, pepper.  Tastes of bitter hops, roasted malt, some molasses.  Decent.
Pours dark black. Nose of chocolate, coffee and heavily roasted malts. Taste is chocolate malts and coffee with a lot of smoke. Smooth and quite smokey.
Pours a dark black with a brown head. Large foamy head! Smells of hops and flowers! Bit of caramel. Tastes similar with coffee aftertaste. Good stuff
Bottle. Pours black with a one finger tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and alcohol. Thick and rich flavor of roasted malts, citrus/piney hops, chocolate, coffee and a bit of toffee.

Bottle courtesy of mitchgt from Greens in Atlanta.  Black pour with a sturdy tan head that leaves a quarter inch.  Aroma of sweet malts, dark fruit, bitter chocolate, coffee, leather and earthy hops.  Tastes are coffee, caramel, grain alcohol, light tropical citrus, dark fruits and plenty of bitter hops mixed in.  Nice creamy medium texture.  Finishes up roasty, dry and bitter.  Excellent

Bottle. Moderrate malt aromas of toasted/burnt, molasses and strong coffee, resin for the hops, earth for the yeast with raisin and cola in the background. Head is small, frothy, off-white with good slippery lacing and good legs and is mostly diminishing. Color is black. Flavor starts slightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and a long heavy bitterness. Palate is medium, oily, with a fizzy carbonation and a dry finish. This Black IPA has it all, great toasted malt backbone, bitter resinous hops with a nice mouthfeel and finish.
very hoppy,smoke, coffee, black, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, salty, medium body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

bottle from superdave no longer 70 on 3/21/2010.

almost black colored pour with a pale brown head.

the aroma is lightly smoky... mixed with resin, chocolate, roast, citrus pith, mild spiciness and odd herbal hops. 

flavor is the same... malty, chocolate-y and rich with a bunch of hoppy dryness and spice. it even burps up resinous and herbal. 

super creamy smooth texture. 7/4/7/4/16/3.8

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2010 50 cl bottle, pours deep dark with a minor creamy head,  aroma is roasted and coffee, taste is roasted malt and coffee nicely balanced with a good hop bitternness, full bodied beer with a nice and smooth finish, not as heavy as one might think and an excellent beer overall.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark black with a fairly thick deep chocolate brown head.  Big chocolate and a bit of roast and coffee over a nice thick citrus and pine hop background.  Medium bodied, full of roast at first, but moving into a slightly sweet and almost oxidized old plums.  Then transitions back into more thick milk chocolate.  Finishes with even more soft bakers chocolate and roast.  Really good.

This is a damn good beer!  Black with a fizzy brown head.  Aroma and taste of floral amber incense and citrus hops, roasted grain and chocolate with a coffee finish.  One of the best beers Ive had lately.
UPDATED: DEC 19, 2010 50cl, new Danish brew Anno 2009, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex bitter Stout, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Bomber shared by Eric. Pours out a wonderful black color with a large thick and creamy brown head. A very odd aroma; roasted hops, somehow I imagine smoked hops. The flavor is very hoppy, not bitter, citrus and pine, smoke, chocolates, odd metallic or even nutty flavors, minty even. Odd and very nice. A great mouthfeel, creamy. I dig this. A European take on the Dark IPA.

Atlanta, Ga - Hop City Craft Beer & Wine - 22 oz bomber. Pours a viscous pitch black with a sticky khaki colored that leaves excellent lacing. Aroma is not as pronounced as the flavor or appearance - pick up some chocolate notes and a hint of coffee with cream. Flavor is rich and bold with lots of dark chocolate, some baked brown bread, a bit of espresso. Thick,  rich mouthfeel. Rather enjoyed this one.

Bomber via Greens in Atlanta.  Ink-black pour with three inch pillowy brown head.  Caramel, malt and bit of citrus on the nose, like a chocolate covered orange.  First sip: Niiice.  Carbonated creamy mouthful.  Not sure exactly where to place it (whats an "American Strong Ale" anyway?), but Ill likely place another one in my celler soon.  Really digging the bitterness.  As it warms emerges vanilla, and something like charred coffee beans.  As it warms further, strong with toffee.  Nice beer.

Bottle from superdave shared at Hellbillys Shootout in Sosco Tasting.  Pours dark brown/near black with a thin tan head.  The nose is citrus hops, chocolate, caramel and alcohol.  The taste is citrus hops, roast, toffee.  Decent.  Thanks Dave!

2/10/2010:  Beer Here Dark Hops Hoppy Black Ale...  Aroma:  Over-ripe citrus hoppiness; just a tinge of chocolate.  Appearance:  As dark or darker than most Imperial Stouts; two finger (or more) head of lasting tan-colored foam.  Flavor:  Dark to bittersweet chocolate and coffee malt, roasty followed by an extremely dry and citrus-like hoppy bitterness; very pleasing mocha flavor left on the palate.  Palate:  Medium-full, smooth.  Overall:  Wow, based on the name I was really expecting a "Black IPA" but this was something altogether different and maybe even better!  It packs both maltiness and a more than generous hop presence and bitter.  The dryness is a bit off-putting at first, but the rich, chocolate/coffee flavor that follows more than makes up for it.  Wow, this beer is definitely unique and unlike anything you might be expecting.
0.5 l bottle (8.5% alc/vol) shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #210 for this beer.

Appearance: Pours a lush dark brown to black with a massive brown crown that displays lots of retention and uber lacing.

Smell: Rye, dark roast malt, resiny hops, dark chocolate, and a slight citrus almond tinge. The resiny hops are my favorite part.

Taste: Malt is roasted much more than the nose led me to believe. It almost has a hint of smoke or char. Also getting fig notes, toffee, and butterscotch. Hops arent as dominant as they were in the nose. A small alcohol tinge is present.

Mouthfeel: Fairly thick but creamy!

Drinkability: This is a pretty hefty brew with a decent abv but it is real tasty!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-03-2009

Bottle. Poured a very black color with a nice two finger creamy tan head. It didnt smell as good as it tasted. Aroma was coffee, funky hops, burnt choclate and milk. Flavor was heavy like a stout. Very rich and complex. Chocolate, coffee, some burnt notes, and hops. I fell in love with this beer. Smelled funky but tasted amazing. I really dont know what it is. I didnt think it was an american strong ale. Some black ipa mixed with imperial stout to me. And thats my two favorite styles.
Surprisingly a very good beer. I hadnt heard of this brewery before but the beer is pretty good. Smells of chocolate, hops, and has a wheaty, barley, and an overall cereal taste. Would drink again.
Opaque dark with espresso cap, sour, chocolate, coffee and dark fruit, cherries, hops of grass and lemon, a bit wine like. Bottle shared with Sammy and Ken courtesy me from Premier.
Black with a large beige head. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malts and hops. taste is of cocoa, roasted malts and hops.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a medium, creamy, tan head, good retention.  Aroma is huge hops (floral, perfume), smoky dark malt, coffee, chocolate, alcohol, and oak.  Flavor is dark chocolate malt, coffee, smoky, bitter floral and pine hops, some alcohol and oak.  Full body, moderate retention.

Courtesy of tpd975. Pours deep dark with mahogany edges and nice tan to mocha head. The aroma is up front hoppy with spicy hops, some floral, some pine and then loads of roast and chocolate and burnt malts. The taste is a pleasing mix of spices, pine hops and some floral hops and then heading into smooth velvety chocolate, roasted malts and a thin layer of burnt malts. The hops, malts, a subtle spiciness really comes together nicely.

Bottle shared with tarheels 86.  Dark brown, slightly murky, pretty brown head.  Aroma of pumpernickel, carroway seeds, hops.  Body is slightly thin, taste is malty, with coffee and bitter cocoa.  Not bad.

500mL courtesy of Travlr. Pours nealry jet black with a thin, very dark, menacing head that has some good rockiness and sticky lace. Aroma is green olive spread, pimento, pesto, salt water. Taste is massive roast, spicy hops, raw cocoa powder. A bit chalky in the mouthfeel. Disappointing.

Jonahs bottle, via Premiere Gourmet.  Pours dark black with fomay brown head abundant, and abundant head.  Roasty aroma.  Pours oul creamy that leads to sucj is above-average mouthfeeel.  Like a hoppy RIS, with chocolate.  Very drinakble.

Bottle at Göteborg Beerfestival 2010-04-23, Göteborg
black, wee heads, chocolate, coffey, vört bread, toffee

Bottle:  The aroma consists of light chocolate, roasted malt, and citrus hops.  It pours a dark brown, virtually black, with a large tan head with good retention.  It definitely looks like an Imperial Stout.  The flavor starts with chocolate and a hint of caramel.  The finish has moderate citrus hops, roast, and a hint of burnt coffee.  Medium-full bodied with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.
Bottle at RBNAG-2009. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is hop, coffee, roasted malt. Flavour is sweet, hop, coffee, roasted malt. Bitter coffee finish. Full body. Nice beer.

500 ml bottle; thanks to beerlando for the trade; dense, black pour with huge chocolate colored head billowing to almost 3 thick; sweet, chalky nose of chocolate, resiny nuts, earthy hops and spice; drinks with a light texture and plenty of dry roast and chocolate; chalky texture with some chocolate and dry, grassy hops; an interesting that seems to blend a few styles together; very dry overall with resiny hops and chocolate; definitely has the roasted malt profile in the robust porter or stout fashion, so Im digging this more than just the overly hopped strong ale I expected; plenty of malt and sweet chocolate to round out and make this a fun one to drink; some fruity notes and grape skin as it warms; very nice overall, though very dry in the end; definitely digging what Ive had from Beer Here so far

Thanks to the Tampa Crew (officerfriendly, I think).  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is dark fruit, dark chocolate, booze, vinegar, fruit, hops, and earth.  Flavor is similar with chocolate and pine hops.  Lingering malt and hops with some earth.  Interesting, complex beer.

In short: An intense Black IPA/Mega-hoppy Stout.  Bold roasted maltiness and brutal bitterness.  Good in small servings.
How: Bottle 500ml.  Consumed fresh a few weeks after purchase
The look: Near black body topped by a medium tan head
In long: The nose is intensely hoppy.  In a blind test I might have guessed IPA/IIPA.  The aroma is a ton of orangey hops with roasted malts underneath.  Taste brings the malts more upfront.  Molasses and burnt malts are the dominant flavors.  milk chocolate, some dark fruits, citrus fruits.  Body is creamy.  A truckload of hops with a signature that is halfway between fresh oranges and fresh green hops.  Very sharp bitterness.  The beer is very tasty, very very tasty, this is as intense as it gets for the style.  But it just feels like a bunch of stuff thrown at me just for the sake of being very tasty.  It took me over 30 minutes to drink a 500ml bottle, unusual for me.  I suspect the current high score on this one comes from a lot of tasting session ratings because this beer is really not something that can be enjoyed by the pints.  Is it well balanced?  Well, imagine an hippopotamus and white rhinoceros playing on a playground teeter-totter.

Bottle. Black with head that looks like the inside of a three muskeers bar. Aroma of huge chocolate, piney and earthy hops, big roastedness. Taste is big roasted chocolate with lingering bitter finish. Chalky cocoa powder taste very present. Enjoyed while watching Phish DVD "IT" with friends.

Believe this one was shared by SuperDave @ Hellbillys.  Thanks Dave!!!  Pretty tasty brew.  Dark leather pour with a khaki head that left a splatter of lacing inside the glass.  Lots of resin and roasted malt...kind of nutty with a tart fruit skin finish.  Interesting.

Dark opaque black with thick tan head, bubbly lace.  Aroma dominated by sweet dark chocolate, little bit of carbon, some oak, hint of flowery hops. Fairly thin, somewhat velvety feel with smooth carbonation.   Starts with the bite of a burnt imperial stout, then some chocolatey sweetness, then piney and resiny hops.  Finishes with grassy hoppy bitterness and carbon burn.  Alcohol is there but not too evident.  Ive been very bored by imperial stouts lately, but this was really interesting.  Its classified here as an American Strong, but it looks, smells, and feels like a stout with a more interesting hop profile.  Really nice, not overpowering, and stays interesting throught the whole bottle, doesnt burn out at all.
Pours dark brown with light brown head. Citrus, toasted malt and chocolate aromas. Flavors of toasted malts, coffee and bitter hops. Medium body with moderate carbonation.
Dark brown pour.  Citrus and spicy hops, light choclate, toffee and some earthy notes in the nose.  Flavor is loaded with citrus hops, light chocolate, malty and a bit tart.
pours a brown with a tan head aroma is hops and roast flavor is roast and hops similar to sublimely righteous but with a fruit twang.

Bottle at Chucks house.  Poured deep brown with a short cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up fresh earthy hops and cocoa powder over rich molasses and coffee maltage.. well-balanced and interesting.  The flavor found molasses and licorice at the core with sour malty notes and earthy bitterness around.. fairly sharp and unbalanced through the finish.  Medium-bodied and slick on the palate.. rough around the edges, and it went downhill after the initial impression.

Bottle from Perrys - thanks Harpreet.  Nose is big with dark, dark chocolate, roasty malt and a lining of resiny hops.  Color is glossy jet black, like a Dark Horizon.  Flavor is thick with those same hops, every bit of that chocolate, maybe a little tart espresso.  Big and dark like a stout.

Wow. I never expected this. Beautiful black with a tan lacing head. Big hop aroma when its opened gives way to a chocolate malt. Flavor is very much chocolate with a nice hop backbone. Aftertaste is mostly hops. Very creamy and smooth going down with no alcohol at all. Dry and warm to finish.

pours dark brown, silky mocha head, ncie lacing.
Aroma of roasted malts, mild hops.
flavor, hard to find the style, the beer has many stout like aspects but the hops add a unique twist.
Hops are definitely present, for a silky palate followed by notes of roasted malts and a mild bitter and smokey finish.
Add some chocolate elements, light booze and warming mouthfeel, some thin yeasty and grainy to be noted.
Tasty.

Thanks to seabass for the share.

A: Pours dark black with a nice mocha colored head. Good retention and lace noted.

S: Lots of roast, green herbal hops, and chocolate.

T: Hopes galore, very green, very herbal. Light citrus notes with a bold roasted undertone. Hints of smoke and more bitter hops in the finish.

M: Medium in body, sort of sharply carbonated.
Black pour with tan head and lace. Chocolate, dried fruit, and earthy hops. Flavor mirrors aroma with a nice malty bitter finish. Medium bodied with good carbonation.

At first ,i got a new tire aroma,like I was walking into Farm and Fleet,this suddenly changed to sharp hops ,which when combined with the alcohol really got your nose tickling,taste good Lord, absolutly the bitterest beer I have ever had,bitter chocolate,and black patent malt,almost syrupy but those hops are insane,this one is truly a tongue bender. Interesting
Bottle. Aroma of hops, malt, coffee and chocolate. Very dark brown colour with light brown head. Bitter, dry grapefruitlike flavour. The complexity disappears in the bitterness.

Bottle. Dark brown color with a big thick tannish head. Nose is earthy hopps and some light chocolate. Palate is full, fizzy and pretty bitter. Flavors of earthy hops, chocolate, some brownies. Finishes sticky.

Dark nearly black pour w/ a gigantic thick oatmeal looking brown head w/ great lacing.  Light rubbing alcohol in the aroma is a no so pleasant surprise. Lots of roasty malts almost charred, with a good grassy hop bitter smell, kind of reminds me of black sun in the aroma. Nice well coated palate feels a little thick.  Nice roasty almost a touch smoky malted aroma a real light touch of vanilla and a light grass hop dry finish.

Pours to a pick black body with a deep brown head and nice lacing.  The aroma is sweet green hops with pine and almost a lemon Pledge thing going on.  The flavor is smoked charred black malt.  Licorice.  Tons of bitter black malt.  The palate is medium bodied, hugely bitter, lightly oily.  Dry.

Bottle. Poured clear dark brown with a large frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted malt, chocolate, earthy hop with a small alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a dry slick texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy dark bitter flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a very good complex beer.

Thick black pour with a thick dark tan creamy head. Chocolate malt, tobacco, roasted grain and anise in the aroma. Taste is smooth chocolate malt, dark fruit, roasted grain and a touch of hop bite. Not overly thick and much more drinkable than most complex stouts.

Suttrees Nothing else to do in Mid-February Tasting. Sample from a bottle thanks to Suttree.  So maybe the beer got better as the night went on, or maybe I drank myself into rating easier.  Anyway, this beer was nice.  Dark brown, toward black with a milk chocolate dark tan head.  Aroma is very roasty, chocolate, coffee.  Taste is roast, chocolates, dark chocolate, coffee, brash hops.

Black, with a brown head. Nice aroma - a mix of raisin, rum some more fruity notes. Flavor is one of those deals where you could just try to list everything and end up with a laundry list, but suffice it to say that there is a nice blend of coffee, several dark fruits, and a nice hop bite. very tasty brew.

Bottle This beer rocks! Pitch black ale with a large, frothy, well-tanned head. Excellent retention. The bouquet releases notes of blackstrap molasses, pouch tobacco, dark chocolate, licorice and earthy, pungent hops. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and subdued carbonation.  The flavor presents everything a terrific imperial stout should  blackstrap molasses, carbon, bittersweet dark chocolate, pouch tobacco and Cuban espresso. Hearty, rich, heavy. Lengthy, bittersweet, burnt finish. This beer really does have all the characteristics of an imperial stout a world class imperial stout.

Strong aroma is oily and smoky with overtones of miso and yeast and hints of caramel and molasses. It pours like motor oil, coming out a warm chocolaty sable with a  very thick and fine-bubbled tan head. Flavor is strongly of molasses with a strong and pleasantly surprising hoppy component and undertones of fine roast coffee and unsweet chocolate as well as a caramel hint. There is also an odd rubbery tone that I usually find with wheat beers. Texture is fairly smooth and not all that tingly, and the finish is both smoky and hop-bitter, an interesting combination.

Bottle from the Wine and Cheese Place.  Pours a deep coffee / cola browns with a creamy tan head, some spotty lacing left on the tulip.  Nose starts off bursting with fresh pine, then gives way to deep roasted malts, coffee, and hints of bittersweet chocolate.  Very hoppy and roasty on the palate with a good amount of cocoa on the back end.

(500ml bottle)  Pours a dark brown (near black) body with a tall creamy tan head.  Aroma of ash, roasted grain, pine, grass, grapefruit, cocoa, anise, and cedar.  Flavor of roasted malt, pine, grass, chocolate, and caramel with a bitter finish.

Nearly opaque black brew with a tall, lasting dark tan head.
Roast malt makes up the aroma.
Roast bitterness with little hop bitterness or flavor.
Rich smooth and full bodied.

50cl bottle courtesy of illidurit.   Im excited that we finally have this available locally because Beer Here is rocking it.   I was a big fan of Mörke pumpernickel porter, but this is probably just as good.   I went into this expecting a black IPA, but found a very nice hoppy stout, with all the necessary malt richness to carry the generous hop bill.   Pours solid black with a tan head.   The aroma is solid chocolate-filled orange as David already suggested below, with some caramel and light smoke.   Very malty smelling, with that nice orange hop fruitiness.   The flavor is dark chocolate and roasty with a bitter hoppy edge and a dry finish.   Medium bodied with a smooth texture.   Really tasty stuff, and as much a hoppy stout as anything.

Very good, a little different than usual. Tastes like a hoppy porter. Starts with heavy, chocolate malts and then a good dose of hops kick in for a lightly bitter finish. Full bodied. Porter like aroma.

Bottle from Beertopia in Omaha. Pours Dark dark brown with massive dark tan head. Nose is loaded with chocolate and roasted malts with good amount of hops and citrus. Flavor is heavy wht roasted malts and chocolate but has big citrus and hops flavors. This is not a black IPA. It is more of a heavily hopper porter or stout. Pretty good stuff regardless of style.

Bottle courtesy Guy411. Pours nearly black with chocolate brown corners and a finely carbonated dark tan head. Aroma is like those Ghirardelli chocolate squares that have orange cream inside. Candied citrus and milk chocolate. Flavor is very rich chewy chocolatey malts with a light smokiness and a hop character that is more piney and herbal than fruity. Big solid bitterness without any astringency. Smooth slick mouthfeel.

Dark Hops
Sampled on 1/2/2010. This American Strong Ale pours a eclipse black color from a 50cl bottle. Large sized tan foamy head with nice lacing and good retention. The aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and hops. A medium bodied ASA. Malts are chocolate and roasty, with a weird touch of ice tea. Hops are floral and citrusy. Nice balance. A decent amount of bitter. More in the Black IPA category. Nice slightly dry finish. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and slightly dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

liquirizia a piu nn posso!! al naso è gia molto presente ma anke accompagnata dai luppoli.. in bokka esplode in un sapore uniko di liquirizia molto persistente ke dura parekkio con un bell amaro finale... un po squilibrata ma gradevole..

0.5 L Bottle. Pours black with a filmy off-white head. Amazing aroma of bittersweet chocolate, licorice and hops. Lots and lots of hops, both earthy and citrus. Initial flavor is dominated by deeply roasted malt and licorice. Finishes with a lingering bitterness. Mouth feel more reminiscent of a porter than a stout.

A Mes rate: bottle at the ever brilliant Chris Os Pre GBBF Extravaganza.Good black body with a tan head. Big coffee, huge dryness, plenty of bitterness and some gorgeous hops. Slight ethanol and prickly alcohol. Great length. Good hops, good malt, excellent beer. Fantastic label too!

Pours a dark brown almost black with a thick frothy medium/dark brown head. The aroma given off is a combo of sweet and sour. the beer smells like it was wet hopped. Notes of coffee and caramel are present with a hop finish. The palate is slightly creamy. The initial flavor is that of a imperial stout/ strong porter, but the finish is rather well hopped.

Bottle @ pre-GBBF shindig, August 2009. It is certainly dark and it most definitely has plenty of hops. Good fresh, perfumed, resinous hops at that. So I guess the name says most of what you need to know. Quite thick and chewy. Burnt malt and bitter coffee on the palate. Flavours are maybe a little harsh and could be a little better integrated. Otherwise excellent.

Very, nearly black color. Tall, lasting dark tan head. Scents of Herbal and citric hops, dark malts, citrus, juniper, molasses, tobacco all waft about. Quite intriguing, but not quite totally inviting. Creamy feel. Licorice start in the flavors set me back a bit (me being a known licorice disliker in my brews). But I escape with minimal damage. Starfruit, and some charred pineapple flavors work in. Seem a bit too charred for my tastes. Not an abundance of flavors for me. The charred licorice and some herbal hops are not enough to sway me.

Pours beautiful dark brown with a two finger dark tan head. Full nose of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate and a bit of nuttiness. Same in the flavor with a decent dose of bitterness in the finish. Medium full mouthfeel.

The maltiest black ipa Ive tried, but awesome nonetheless.  Slight citrus in the aroma combines with charred malts, chocolate, and molasses notes.  Flavor is slightly sweet, slightly bitter with a nice hop finish.  Dark fruit flavors make themselves present, underscored by bitter citrus and slight pine.  Really good brew.

"Hops were hurt in the making of this beer"

I just recently heard about a beer thats a combination of my two favorite styles of beer. Imperial stout, and IPA. And i knew i had to try it. Dark Hops by Beer Here is that beer.

Poured into a tulip glass. Black with no light showing at all. One finger of a roasted hazelnut color head with tremendous lacing that hugs the glass for dear life.

Smell is very hoppy. Mostly citrus hops. Chocolate and roasted malts with some caramel and coffee also.

Well can literally taste this beer change flavors in your mouth. First you get hit with the citrus hop bite and slowly it warms as you swallow and turns to a roasted chocolate flavor and finishes tasting big time of coffee.

Mouthfeel is rich and medium to full bodied. Finishes super creamy with a tremendous after taste.

This is a hell of a beer! Best of both worlds. Hops, coffee, chocolate, alcohol. What more could you want. This beer is really a good time. Im glad i found this. I recommend you going out and getting one if you can find it.

Aroma of roasted malt, cocoa, roasty coffee, maybe a bit of cedar. Flavor rich with semi-sweet chocolate and lots of roasted malt. Toffee and nougat notes emerge more and more. Good dose of bitterness, but this felt a lot more like a straight stout to me, not a black ipa/asa sort of deal. Just loads of rich, vinous malt. Very tasty.
( .5L bottle thanks to bu11zeye) Pours black with tan head and great lacing. Nose of chocolate, well integrated hops, brown sugar. Taste of semi-sweet chocolate, cocoa, with a creamy/thick body.

Impressive tan head that recedes in sugarloaf like dome.  Leaves extensive lace on the glass.  Near black color where no light shines through.

Dark, dark chocolate aroma.  No powerful hop overwhelming the smell although I expected it: "hoppy black ale".

A complex combination of a dry porter start, a hoppy-ish middle, and a bitter burnt unmalted finish.  The body is rich without being thick.

Bottle.  Pours thick and black with a huge, foamy dark tan head.  Aroma of oak, cedar, wood, hop spices, roasted malt.  Flavor of charred/roasted malt, more oak, and some light citrus/bitter hops in the finish.  More of a hoppy stout to me but quite tasty!
8/4/8/4/15 [3.9/5]

Jet black with a big brown and creamy head with very good retention. Nice lacings. A fine looking brew.

The smell has pleasant fresh hop aromas up front. Floral notes, hop resins, some citric notes. Faint spices. The hops blend nicely with a roasted malty backbone with nice coffee and chocolate aromas. A very good and fascinating smell.

The hops are up front in the mouth as well, and they are quite aggressive. Very fresh hop flavors, floral notes, resins and perhaps some grapefruit. However, the hops are not as powerful as in the smell, nor as complex. Nice foundation of roasted malts, big coffee flavors, chocolate. Perhaps some spices, faint vanilla and licorice. The finish is rather bitter with pleasant flavors of roasted malts, pine-needles, hop resins and wood. All in all, a very nice taste with a beautiful mix of fresh hops and the "usual" stout flavors of coffee and chocolate.

M: Medium body going towards full. Quite alot of carbonation actually that slightly bothers me. But other than that, this is a really good beer.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Pours as dark and thick as any imperial stout I have seen, dark brown head.  Aroma is certainly not imperial stout, more like a double IPA, with a crisp, piney aroma with just a hint of coffee.  Flavor is quite nice, never had anything quite like it.  More juniper like hops, with a bit of coffee and baking chocolate.

(bottle) black with generous tan head, nice lace. Aroma of roast malt, moist earth (Ive got a cold, perhaps thats why Im missing the hops). Flavor is roast malt, coffee, dark chocolate, with a bitter hops finish
Bottle @ Pauls gathering. Well very enjoyable black ipa here, hops and dark mals can coexist even thrive. Up there with my favorite "normal" ipas, and has a mouthfeel than the norm.

Bottle. Pours like Guinness. Dark black with a six-finger head that "sheets" down into fluid. Sort of an earthy hop aroma. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Seems to be a lot of dark toast malt and some coffee. Not all that bitter. Definitely a strong hop aroma, though. Pretty different. Heading for stout, but not there. Good change of pace.

.5 liter bottle.  Pours a deep dark clear brown near black with a fluffy tacky head- some lace.  Aroma is some dank weed like hops but skews towards the minty green hops some citrus light grapefruit- mixes ok with a light chocolate nuttiness- low to no roast.  Flavor is chocolate and hops, clean, toasty sweet malts, but not thick and doesnt get in the way of the green hops- citrus, pine mint and earthy cocoa fresh tobacco leaf casing to a cigar- nice.  Smooth and lingering bitter finish.

Heard this was pretty good, so I was excited to see it at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee.  I am suspicious, though, as it is apparently contract brewed at Nogne O.  Roasty, chocolate aroma with leafy hops.   Flavor is coffee, chocolate, mint, and some light bitterness. Medium roastiness.  Full on the palate with a creamy texture.  Reminded me of smoking a cigar and eating mint chocolate ice cream.  Nice carbonation for the style, and finishes roasty.  Pretty solid beer here.

Bottle into Snifter, Honolulu, Liquor Collection. Pours black with great head with good retention, big and rocky, a light brown color. Opaque black color that is clear. A round medium sweet taste with a fizzy mouth feel on the tip of the tongue. The tingling sensation seems to stay for awhile. I was expecting more.
Black color with a brown head. Aroma is maximum hop, roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is also hop and roasted malts and chocolate notes. Sweet and long aftertaste. Enjoy.

Bottle.  Pours a thick and very dark brown with a dense medium-sized head.  Aromas are interesting and different than expected.  A pretty chocolate malt base with a mint and tobacco smoke oddness about it.  Flavor is far less compelling than I was expecting.  Its not bad, but its kind of odd.  Fairly smokey/peaty with lots of chocolate and mint/pine hops thrown in.  It doesnt balance together that great, however.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
[PERSONAL NOTES] brown foam, rocky head, black, smoke, sticky, medium body,
Nice, but the finish is to abrubt! ikke bitter nok.

Bottle at ChrisOs pre-GBBF tasting, 1st Aug 09. Pitch black with a thick tan head. Loads of light hops but also tar, Vosene and other subtle medicinal notes. Rich and full with nice roasted notes coming through as you savour it. Good stuff.

Very bitter ale, or stout.  Almost black, clear, light brown head, mostly lasting. Aroma is grain, burnt, mild coffee, heavy hopped, licorice, faint medicine. Moderate sweet flavor, heavy bitter. Dry texture. Lively carbonation.

Filthy brew. Emmmmmmmm pure effing dommy. Awesome hop stout aroma, but the flavor was just a hopped chocolate with no coffee. Kind of like a really good bitter dark chocolate in a beer, but instead of lots of chocolate it had more floral/pine hops. Awesome beverage.
Bottle. Pours near black with a tan head. Roasted malty aroma with fruity citric hops. Strong roasted malt flavor with bitter citric hops and a lasting roasty and bitter finish. Quite good.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 My 1500th rating! Bottle. Pours a dark creamy shinny near black with a tall airy foamy lighter mocha colored frothy head, very similar two the Morke and also very Nogne.  Aroma of bright sweet citrus and chocolate cookies, lots of juicy hoppy citrus, pineapples, sharp resinous pine, some plastic and alcohol.  Woa, flavor is tar, lots of alcohol, plastic, dark chocolate cookies, some dark syrupy burnt molasses, the sweet citrus is actually pretty nice once you get used to the initial bitterness/charred flavor, finishing very ashy and quite quick.  Medium bodied with a fuller mouth-feel, creamy, sharp fizzy larger spread-out carbonation, quite drinkable.  Definitely has more flavor than the Morke, lots of similarities though in the overall feel.

Bottle. A crazy mix of really roasty coffee, citrusy/pineapple hops, and a little malt sweetness. Bitter hop, coffee flavor. Really weird, and the combination doesnt work at all. Reminds me of Allagashs Burnham Road as it exhibits a pairing of flavors that just shouldnt be mixed at all -- in this case, coffee and citrus, in that case sweet smoke and Belgian yeast.

50cl bottle.  Large brown head atop black body with brown edging.  Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, roast, some coffee, ash, bittersweet chocolate.  Taste is medium sweet, ash, roast, bittersweet chocolate, grapefruit.  Watery medium body, very drinkable, alcohol near invisible.

Black. Large creamy brown head and excellent lacing. Cocoa, caramel, lemon and lime on the nose. Roasted coffe adds to the aroma once in the mouth. Heavily bitter, moderately sweet and lightly acidic. Long finish. Medium bodied, dry texture.
Batch # 407. 
(Bottle, courtesy of tarjei 12.12.2009)

Source: Hop City, Atlanta
Appearance: black, fine tan head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet citrus hop aroma, roasted and chocolate malt
Body: big sticky body
Flavor: big roasted malt flavor, sweet caramel brings out a chocolate character that leaves a bitter dark chocolate in its wake, lots of citrus and sweet resiny pine, light bitterness from the roast

Appearance: black, creamy tan head
Aroma: aroma starts off with heavy roast followed by the citrus and then sweet pine rounding it out
Flavor: rich roasted flavor, lots of citrus hops, sweet pine

Black with a dense brown head. Roasted aroma with coffee, chocolate  and citric hops. The flavour is initially sweet marked by the roasted malts, and then turns into a nice bitter, yest still roasted ending.
Poured very black, coffee, roasted malts, herbal hops, little dark chocolate.

22oz bottle @Pauls Gathering Thanks Victor/vferg-pours a light brown head and dark brown color.  Aroma is sweet pine hops, some medium/dark malt.  Taste is sweet pine/herbal hops, some medium/dark malt-peat.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours deep black with tan head, very nice looking beer. Aroma is very balanced, dark roast and some coffee, light hop. Flavor of some coffee, dark roasted grain, malty, nice light hoppiness. Mouth feel is heavy body with medium-high carbonation. Overall, not bad at all!

50cl bottle from K&L Redwood City.  Pours black in color with a huge brown head that strangely has two layers, a lower brown one and an upper tan one.  Ridiculous retention.  Aroma is roast, coffee, piney hops, and a hint of smoke.  Flavor is very good, with all the characteristics of a roasty stout: roasted malt, caramel malt, coffee, and bitter chocolate, along with a blast of piney and resinous hops, maybe a little citrus too.  Mouthfeel is very smooth and body is fairly full.  Very nice beer overall.

Bottle: Pours an oily opaque with a large airy dark beige head.  Has a fresh grapefruity resiny hop nose supported by sweet dark caramel malt and dark chocolate.  Starts with pretty good fullness and dark malty sweetness with some roasted coffee bean notes and a nice balance of citrusy flavor and bittering hops.  An enjoyable and dangerously drinkable hoppy dark ale.

Pours black into a snifter.  Mocha head with excellent retention slowly recedes leaving sheets to skim surface. Dark pit fruit, chocolate and espresso aromas. Creamy yet lively chocolate upfront turning to sweet resin and grapefruit and back to chocolate in the lasting finish.

500ml Bottle. Classic label, alien hops Men in Black style. Thick, black pour with a half inch layer of tan froth that laces beautifully.  Loved the aroma, smells like freshly cut pine, roasted grain and chocolate chip cookies.  Flavor is heavily roasted with significant char taste.  A little chocolate and hop resin are present behind all that roast.  Bitterness abounds throughout each sip, but isnt overblown. Mouthfeel is medium, with an oily texture and lively carbonation. Sharp, dry and bitter finish on the back of the tongue. More like a very hoppy, roasted porter than an IPA to me. Enjoyed this one, but would have liked a little less roast and a more prominent hop flavor.

Black pour with a huge and fluffy tan head.  Aroma is is of chocolate and citrus hops.  Full bodied with high carbonation.  Sweet flavor, bitter chocolate with a resinous piney/citrus hoppiness.  Lingering citrus aftertaste.  I didnt think this one would work.  It is unique, complex and tasty.

Pitch black with a huge dark brown head that leaves very nice lazings. Aroma is extremely hoppy and roasted with notes of caramell. Flavour is intense roasted and "green hoppy" with a dry caramell finish. Very flavourfull yet balanced, drinkable and fun.

Bottle.Pours darker than northern Norway on the Winter Solstice at 2 am.  Aroma is cigarette ash, cocoa, and coffee.  Flavor is brackish coffee and cocoa, roasted nut, and a smoky hops finish.  Thick and coating on the tongue.  Very strong and assertive.  No bull with this one.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: 500 ml bottle purchased by my Dad at Zipps in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Pour is a murky brown black, with a thick 3 inch deep tan head, which falls with beautiful coating. This was much darker looking than I was expecting, which is odd since it has the word "Dark" in its title.  Aroma is roasted malt and bright fresh pine hoppiness. These two aromas really work together, melding nicely and fresh smelling. Taste is the roast up front with the pine and straw taking the middle and finish. Taste is really quite simple, just the two flavors, but as with the nose nicely melded. Palate is bright active carbonation with a medium to light mouthfeel and a clean bitter finish. Aftertaste reveals only a hint of alcohol. This was unique and well crafted beer, nice one. Pretty much a hopped up big porter, but super drinkable.

Completely black body with a big, foamy brown head. Strong aroma of hops, coffee and roasted malt. Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, rather bitter, citric and lots of coffee. A big and powerful beer, still very balanced and complete. Long, nice malty and bitter finish.

500mL bottle.

Pours a seriously dark brown out of the bottle and is an opaque black in the glass with a massive dark tan, creamy head that shows great retention and lacing.  A fantastic looking beer.

The aroma is interesting as the first thing I notice is the green herbal hops with hints of citrus.  But there is also a big roasted dark malt presence with dark chocolate as well.  Two big and bold aromas competing for supremacy.

The taste starts with a huge herbal, almost spicy, green hop kick - extremely bitter on the tongue from start to finish.  behind the bitterness is the dark roasted malts, which take on an almost charred character in the finish with the hops bringing an astringent bitterness at the same time.  Whoa.

The mouthfeel is medium to full-bodied but feels a little lighter than that at times due to the massive herbal hop profile which keeps the malts from settling in.  Lots of carbonation as well, maybe a little too much, but thats being picky.

I wouldnt call this one extremely drinkable but its still fun to drink with all the competing flavors popping on the palate at once.  Very creative and quite tasty.

20091116  500ml bottle from State Line.  Nearly black, viscous, a bit murky, with thick and lasting dark brown head.  Aroma is roasted, rich, chocolaty, grapefruit, gin, spruce, and cigar ash.  Medium to full bodied up front with slight thinning and aggressive eff across the middle and late ashy astringency and some quite harsh pithy bitterness.  Flavor adds some tootsie roll, tobacco and licorice notes, but also some unfortunate vinyl and burnt rubber.  Im sure Ive had this before, but I dont recall when or with whom.  Okay stuff.

courtesy of Laurent Mousson - dark black coloured with a persistent beige foam; fair roasted coffeish aroma with notes of walnut; quite astringent, medium to full malt backbone, very bitter coffeish and vanilla finish
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. The look is dark brown in color, dark, and has a biege colored head.  The smell is malts, hops, roasty, and good.  The taste is roasty, malts, hops, and coffee.  Good

Bottle, 8.5% ABV, as Beer Here Dark Hops Hoppy Black Ale, RBNAG 2009 in Vatlandsvåg. Brewed at Nøgne Ø, Norway. Pitch black colour, moderate brown head. Very nice aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate, hints of liquorice. Distinctly roasty flavour, very dry, notes of strong bitter coffee, hints of dark bitter chocolate. Good, but Id like a little more sweetness.

Large choco brown head, good retention and decent lace. Black in color. Nose is got C hops, roast and chocolate. Body is med/full, oily on the palate. Nicely balanced chocolate citrus flavors, licorice, faint tobacco and a bit phenolic. Finish is dry and hoppy. A garoovy brew! Bottle procured @statelineliquors.

yep.  dark and hoppy.  bottle.  a mix of polar opposites.... 2ipa and imp stout.  really too much going on to single any one great quality from this beast.  my palate cant take this kind of punishment.

500 ml from Perrys @ Livermore. Aroma is thick chocolate malt. Pours a dark as night black with brown head that sticks around.  Flavor is dark and roasty like a stout. Some hops, but mostly it tastes like a stout. Decent, but not as much of a Black IPA as I was expecting.
500mL bottle from DK. Pours black with tan frothy head. Nose has some smoke and piney hops. Taste has some roasted malts, more smoke and lmore grassy hops. A strange beer, but tasty.

Bottled. Poured black with a lively, dense, foamy brown head. Nose was roasty, with a hint of floral hops and spices. Falvor was coffee, smoke, and alcohol. A huge hop finish rounded things out, with a nice, bitter hop resin ending. Thick, bold, and immensely satisfying.

Poured thick black with a caramel head, nose surprisingly was not hops, but of smoky and coffee malt.  Tasted as such, with a very present hop bitterness from the hops.  Overall a good strong porter like ale, not a hoppy/black IPA
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Opaque pour. Aroma coffee, chocolate, smoke, citrus. Flavor is smoky, BBQ, wood. Nice mouthfeel.

Excellent pour with a black body and a massive, creamy, dense, dark tan head which settles in time to a creamy, frothy layer and leaves plenty of frothy lace rings; must be the Grimstad water from Nogne that produces these perfect heads.  Nose is very pleasant with lots of pine, orange zest, light grapefruit, plenty of dark chocolate, burnt toast, roasted walnuts, toasted molasses, and some restrained coffee roast.  Flavor is nice but a bit of a letdown with lots of bakers chocolate, burnt toast, pine needles, light earthy rustic, cocoa, and light orange zest.  Palate is very silky smooth, nearly lively, medium to full, but fairly short flavor progression.  Finish is fairly short but nice with faint orange zest, rustic and pine, bakers chocolate, and light burnt toast.  At first, I thought this would be a black IPA hybrid, but actually the moderate bitterness portrays more of an Imperial Porter with plenty of finishing hops.  I wish there were just a bit more sweetness in the flavor and a longer flavor progression.  I really did like this one and it did not contain any unlikable notes like their Pumpernickel Porter.  The more I try, the more I enjoy it, despite the fact that I was not a huge fan of the flavor.  Nose and appearance were exceptional.

500 ml bottle poured a clear dark brown nearly black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, pine, orange zest, cocoa and earthiness. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth with a lightly dry finish. Flavors of bitter chocolate, roasted malt, orange zest, earthiness and light pine with a smooth lingering bitter chocolatey orange finish.

Bottle from EZ. Pours out black with a moderate tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, citrus hops and some roasted malts. Chocolate is right up front with some roasted malts, burnt wood, slight smoke and some citrus hops in there too, put that all together with a rather smooth mouthfeel and this is a pretty solid beer. The only issue I had was that I was searching for a little more upfront hop flavor.

50cl bottle - man, what an amazing pour - thick black ale, with a huge, frothy tan head, with one of those dark swirls in the middle that makes it look like the froth on a cappuccino - this beer is pretty much a very dry, very hoppy imperial stout - strong hops in the nose, with intense roastiness, char, and cedar in the nose - some anise and chocolate underneath that - full, creamy mouthfeel - very dry, roasty, and bitter (both from the hops and the black malts) - strong notes of wood and char, some tobacco - some acidity, and even a touch of sourness through the middle - some chocolate and licorice sweetness arrives late, but mostly this is intensely bitter, dry, and roasty, with faint hints of smoke on the back - I like it!
Bottle courtesy of bu11zeye. Very dark brown pour. Has some smoke on the nose that turns aged beefy. Taste is sharp chocolate upfront with some smoked flavor as well.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  black with a light khaki head.  nose is bittersweet chocolate and citrusy hops.  great on the palate with a thick flavor of roasted chocolate and light hops in the finish.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with a large mocha colored head and a black body. Aroma of molasses, black tar, maple, smoke and hops. Taste is slightly smokey, with hops and bitter chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel. Nice.

Well this sure was a different experience!  Looks and tastes like a stout, but finishes like a strange barrel-aged pale.

Opaque jet black pour with a perfect tan head that thins, but lasts forever as a thin disc.  Oddly active lace just cant seem to stick, but leaves wild patterns.  Smells like burned grains.  Flavor is black coffee, scorched caramel, oak, vanilla, resiny/spicy hops.  Finish is a little off, and the alcohol becomes apparent.

Smooth, fairly thick texture that is pretty pleasant, but its hard to overcome that twinge of odd flavor at the end.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, dark brown, mostly lasting.
Body is opaque black (flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain/nuts, dark chocolate), moderately hoppy (resin), with notes of vanilla and chalk.

Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent.

Holy cow, whats with all the sourness?  The Morke was fairly sour as well, although not this bad.  So its probably as the brewer intends, but seriouisly...undrinkably sour, and quite astringent to boot.  So, the mouth experience is pretty unpleasant other than the thick, creamy texture.  Aroma is decent enough, but nothing special (and overhopped for my tastes in a stout, which is of course what this is).  Hop aroma is pretty much entirely the crude, resinous variety.  Looks amazing, but thats it.
Large creamy dark lasting head and a black body. Heavy hop aroma - not much else. Full body, oily and sticky texture and a bitter finish. Moderate sweet and heavy bitter. Warming.

At the Ølfestival, Esbjerg, Denmark 22-10-09.   Pours dark brown in colour peeling away at the edges to a lighter brown. Very roasty and full flavoured with the addition of crisp fresh hoppy needles also in the mouth. Really nice beer.  A7 A4 F8 P4 Ov16   3.9

Bottle.

The beer looked very nice, black as night with a big brown foam.

Aroma contains a lot of dark chocolate, coffee, and burnt tones. Also a little vanilla and some flowers.

The taste was not bad, a lot of coffee and chocolate just like in the aroma. Citrus, floral and some licorice was there also. Body was medium. Long aftertaste with a lot of bitterness. Interesting beer.

Pours pitch black with a thick tan head, perfect score for a stout or porter, or whatever this beer thinks it is. Aroma is perfect for a double IPA. Grapefruit, hops, and then some dark malts, chocolate, coffee. Flavor of coffee, chocolate, and citrus. Its a collision of two of my favorite styles! I like it!

Bottle. Dark brown-black beer with a brown head. Hoppy aroma with backing light roast and chocolate. Chocolate and light espresso flavor with licorice and piney hops. Medium bodied. Some bitterness. Licorice and light choclate lingers with pine and a light earthiness. It just doesnt do it for me - too many different flavors.

Bottle from Davis Food Co-op. Pours black with a massive brown head and a strong chocolate aroma. The flavor is chocolate, coffee and treacle and is very rich. It is also quite hoppy for a such a malty brew, providing some balancing bitterness toward the finish.

Bottle.50cl. What a color and what a head, it is dark and oily and sticky and lively and bitter and rocky head again, again, again. But this beer is a looker the taste is a bit out of balance for my taste, but never the less it is a good beer.

Bottle from SL. Poured into party cup on my regular Blue Hen tailgate (while walking from remotely parked car to stadium after dropping kids and wife off closer). Dark brown black pour with a brown colored head, generous in size, had to pour and chug a few sips before getting it all in there (undersized). The aroma was hoppy (citrus and pine) roasty. The flavor featured dark roasty malts, coffee, chocolate, some licorice, along with generous pine and citrus bitter hop balance at the end, coming off a bit like an imperial porter. Mouthfeel was smooth and full, yet clean/dry from the hops. A pretty nice brew, although I dont want to know how much I paid for this one.

Black color with a thick head.  A strong, chocolatey, piney hop aroma.  If you inhale enough, theres some wet hop there.  Lots of chocolate and roasty flavor.  Strong bitterness with a little pine hop flavor.  Slightly chalky.  Thick mouthfeel.  Id say its just a little less roasty than an American Imperial Stout, like Storm King.  Great brew.

16.9 oz bottle from EZ Liquors. Pours a viscous pitch black with a large foamy deep mocha brown colored head that turns into a more creamy slick of head and leaving big globs of lace on my Lucifer snifter. Aroma was hoppy overall with notes of cola, light chocolate, grass, citrus, earth, and a touch of soy. Thick full body that is very creamy with a good touch of carbonaton and a full bitter bite in the end. Flavor suprisingly has lots of roastiness that compliments the bitterness nicely. Notes of citrus, pine, coffee grounds, chocolate, burnt toast, slight chocolate. This one is interesting in all the right ways and is one well done beer.
Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, liquorish, citrus hop. Flavour is sweet roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, liquorish, citrus hops, hoppe aftertaste. Very nice.

[Bottle] Pours pitch black with a huge brown head that lingers and leaves great lacing. Beautiful aroma of citric hops, coffee, milk chocolate, and roasted malts. Thick mouthfeel has tons of juicy, citric hop character. The maltiness is sweet at first and mellows down to a roasty dryness on the finish. The hoppy bitterness also comes through on the finish. What a great beer!

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty hoppy grapefruit and citrus aroma. Roasted malty caramel flavor with hoppy bitter grapefruit hints. Has a long hoppy bitter finish with hints of chocolate in the aftertaste.

Very nice, hoppy stout.  This beer pours deep and dark, opaquely black.  The liquid actually seemed quite viscous during the pour.  It feels like a heavy glass of beer, though the hops and roasted malt balance out this weight on the palate.  Anyway, the head is thick, creamy and mocha-colored.  The beer smells quite good.  Its floral and a bit piney with some deep coffee/chocolate malt character.  I was expecting more hops and more aroma punch, but whats there is quite nice and hardly the mess thats possible with this sort of experimentation.  The flavor is just wonderful and delivers the hop punch that I expected in the aroma.  Its mostly a bitter bite, but there are some citric/pine notes around the edges and at the finish.  The malt flavors are round and full.  Theres a lot of roast, some fruitiness, prunes and raspberries, and an excellent coffee note.  Id call it a stout, but the hopping makes the strong ale categorization understandable.  Really good beer.  Im excited that were getting Beer Here in San Francisco.

#3300 Bottle.  Pours a black body with a thick three finger coffee head, with great retention.  Coffee and a roast y hoppy body.  Roast y coffee dry earth, coco notes.  Chocolate and a light pine note.  Citrus kissed coffee and roast y body.  Roast y plumy body with a mild warming.  Awesome Beer!  Let me say that again, awesome beer!

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2012 50 cl bottle. Black body with brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, hops, chocolade and citrus. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, hops, little sweet, pine and medium bitter.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2010 It poured a pitch black liquid with a medium sized light brown foam. It had a strong smell of both hops, citrus and chocolate and coffey. It tasted similar with a combo of hops and all the flavours I relate to a stout. Smooth, creamy and complex. This is a kind of beer Ive been talking about making. Combining lots of hops with a spicey stout. Very nice I really enjoyed it!
Bottle.Bitter hops and bitter malt in a ultra bitter combo without finesse.

Bottle at SBWF.
Pours beautiful black with a brown head

Orange peel, hops, malt, chocolate.

A bit to much of everyting to be great

Bottle from Frank Smiths.  Pours blackish and hazy, with strong piney hop, dark malt, and some citric notes.  Tastes malty, very piney, hoppy, and crisp, reminding me of a souped up black IPA with more malt presence.

[Sampled with the duo Svoger & Svogergylp at DØE, Valby, 2009.] Another great funny beer. Combinationstyles must be the new word. Black with many citric-hops dominated with roast, chocolate, but also some easy-swallow feeling in this beer!

Black colored with medium sized beige head. Rich hopped chocolaty and roasted aroma with thin perfumy tone too. Extremely rich aroma. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is more roasted with rich flowery-grassy hops, some caramelly tone also here. Aftertaste is roasted and hopped still, excellent beer.

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2009, Valby. Pours a very dark beer with a lightbrown head. The aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and licorice. The flavor is soft, rounded with roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. The palate is very nice and good. Overall this beer is one of my favorites.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of hops, pine, light citrus, and hints of cocoa and malts.  Poured black in color with a large, dense, brown head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of medium-sized particles throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of hops, pine, light coffee, light roasted malts, slight cocoa, light citrus, and slight rye.  Medium body.  Lightly tingly, lightly dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Hoppy, pine, light roasted malt, and slight coffee finish.  8.5%ABV is undetectable.

Bottle from Gammel Strand. Very dark brown with a huge, light brown head. Vinous and roasted coffee aroma, quite a bit of tart berries, but also pine and vanilla. Rich coffee and vanilla flavours, vinous berries just in the background, good roasted and hoppy dryness. Piney hop bitterness provides an interesting twist. Warming alcohol. Original and well-made.

What a pleasant surprise this one was.  Poured very dark brown with a rich brown head.  The aroma has lots of smooth rich roasted malt, cream, vanilla and some hops (earthy / piny / citrus) hiding in the back.  Medium / thick body that has a bit of crispness an some sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with much of what is on the aroma, but there is now a pronounced roasty bitterness and some coffee-like traits.  The finish has some earthy hops and roast leading to a very bitter finish.  The warmer this gets the more charred the malt tastes.  Very nice beer to say the least.

1pt .p oz bottle. Poured a dark, dark black color with a large sized off white head. Aromas of floral hops, pine, roast, and some chocolate. For some reason, it also reminded me the seaweed in miso soup (or maybe Im just craving Japanese for dinner). Tastes of roast, floral hops, toasted caramel, and chocolate. Bitter finish. This one was enjoyably different.
An odd beer. IPA meets pitch black. Almost a thin porter. Dark. Hoppy. Very interesting.

It is black with a huge, creamy, light brown and lasting head. While still cold, the aroma is quite hoppy, like smelling dried hops or hop pellets, but as it gets warmer the roasted malt notes of licorice comes out of hiding. The flavour has a light sweetness and a lot of hops, almost killing the roasted malt notes. But again, as it gets warmer, they come along too, mostly with licorice notes. The finish has a good bitterness. A very interesting and quite nice beer.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a big foamy tan head.  Nose is orange and pine with sweet touches of toffee and chocolate.  Silky in the mouth with tiny carb prickles.  Taste is bitter chocolate, grapefruit peel and juniper; a bit chalky.  Lingering licorice, pith and chewed grass.  Another solid Danish brewer albeit via Norway.

Bottle 50 cl. Dragged up from the cellar... maybe the effect of the dryhoppin has faded a bit - but here goes. Pours a pitch black with a foamy coffee brown head. The roma is smokey and acid-like at the same time. The hops are very present with a bitter caracter. The mouthfeel is thick with a creamy lasting feel. The taste is not balanced and is sooo bitter that it takes over the picture from the caramel, vanilla, the smokeyness and chocolate that are there somewhere...but way to far away. Its not balanced...not acording to my universe anyway.
Bottle @ 3 små rum: Dark colour, with a nice head. Aroma of caramel,choclate, some citrus, and fruity nose too. Flavor is almost the same here. Big body and a nice long finish.

Bottle 50cl.Clear dark black color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is light heavy malty, roasted, burnt, light heavy hoppy, grapefruit. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090515]

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a huge dark brown head. The aroma has strong notes of roasted malt and citrusy/grapefruity hops as well as medium notes of chocolate. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of chocolate, roasted malt, and citrusy hops, the roasted malt grows in intensity towards the end, and becomes almost burnt, and leads to a very bitter and roasted finish - seems like the bitterness comes mainly from the roasted malt. The alcohol leaves a slight burn in top of the throat.

Bottled at Tre små rum, Gothenburg
Black with a large, beige head.
Tar, licorice, flowery hops and grass in bopth aroma and flavour; stronger in the aroma.
Sweet, full-bodied and burnt.
Medium bitterness.
Bottle at 3 Små Rum, Göteborg. Tar and licorce aroma, vioo, floral notes, vinous, some hops. Hoppy licorice flavor, quite roated, tar and coffee. Quite bitter, metallic.

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Dense creamy brown head. Chcolate, roast, herbs and liqourice in the aroma. Flavour of rast, chcolate, spice, cocoa, coffee, light herbs and ligourice. Quite dense and distinct flavour. Medium to full bodied. Roast bitter int he end. Nice.

Bottle, 50cl - Black opaque beer with a large brown head. Aroma is roasty malty with notes of coffee, herbs, tobacco, leather and Chuck Norris. Hard roasted malts dominate the flavor with notes of chocolate, coffee, tar and herbal hops. Very complex and interesting beer.

50 cl bottle from 3 SMå Rum, Göteborg, on August 7, 2009Batch 407, brewed 280109, BB 280114Black volor, huge light brown head. Fresh green hoppy scent, a bit roasted malt in the background. Roasted, malty, alcohol, bitter, chocolate taste. Grainy and alcohol aftertaste. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.

From a bottle (50 cl, thanks gnoff for the sips) at café 3 små rum, Göteborg, Sweden. Black with a reddish edge, creamy brown head. Roasted malt aroma, with some fresh green pepper notes. Meidum bodied and smooth. Well balanced, dry with a firm long bitterness. Very nice.
Bottle. Black body, with a large brown head. Aroma is hops, chocolate and grapefruit. Flavor is also hops, chocolate, grapefruit and notes of coffee.
Bottle at Copenhagen Beerfestival 09. Dark color, short head. Hoppy aroma, caramel malt, coffee, chocolat. Good bitter taste, bit sticky, malty. Good stuff.

Bottled (Pikkulintu, brygget 01/2009, batch #407). 
Brewed @Niogne O. Opaque black, small steady cocoa tan head, good lacing. Hops, licorice and roasted notes. Taste has lots of licorice, some hops, but more roasted than bitter. Long roasted, licorice aftertaste. More stout/impy than ASA. A bit wineous. Probably beer which would be interesting to age.  This is like drinkable version of Dark Horizon 2nd edition :)

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2009 Bottle. Black colour with a brown head. Aroma: Green piney hops, roasted malt, mint/menthol, grape. Flavor: Heavily roasted, green hops, pine resin, grape, espresso, a bit of saltiness, some licorice. Roasted and bitter finish. Nice maltiness, but a bit less hops would make it even better. Re-rated 091018.

Bottle, big thanks to Alexander for this one too. Pours a black color with a big, stable, creamy brown head - looks amazing. Aroma is hoppy with citrus, grapefruit, pine needles, resin and pineapple, with some light notes of roasted malt/chocolate in the background, but its the hops which is dominating here, and I like it! Flavour is hoppy with good amounts of pine needles, resin, citrus and grapefruit. Some dark chocolate together with liquorice and toffee is found underneath all the hops. Theres also some special Nøgne Ø-like feel over it, which seem to be some sort of house-flavour found in Nøgne Ø beers and the Mikkeller and Beer Here beers brewed there. Long, bitter finish, which almost lasts forever. Fullbodied on the palate, quite oily and creamy mouthfeel. Perfect carbonation. An awesome beer! Would love to try more Beer Here products after this (and Essentia Bina). Wow!

This might be as close as an amarican strong ale gets to a impy without actually being one. 
Near black with a tan, chunky head. Aroma is malty, smoky and hoppy. The flavour is heavy on the malts with notes of smoke and roasted malt as well as a solid, spicy hop flavour. Ends quite bitter and medium dry.

Bottle at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2009. Black color, lovely brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, hops. The flavor starts like an imperial stout, then the hoppy bitterness takes over, leaving you with a dry hoppy mouth. After a while you get used to it, and then this beer is just lovely. I´m glad I soon have some bottles in my cellar. I almost forgot to mention that this beer is brewed at Nøgne Ø, Grimstad, Norway.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2009 On tap at Copenhagen Beerfestival. It pours a black body under a small, brown head. Some salty licorice, roasted malts and coffee, as well as citrusy hops in the aroma. The flavor has some alcohol and a fine sweetness, yet feels rather dry. Coffee, hints of licorice and citrusy hops too. Nice bitterness. Smooth, velvety, full-bodied, dry and warming mouthfeel. The finish has a lovely citrus-peel like bitterness and roasted malts giving some bitterness too. A lovely one, blending dark malts and hops in a delicious way. Rating: 8-4-8-5-16-4.1. 090517Bottle. A dark, more or less black beer with a bit, creamy, tan head that lasts. Citrusy, piney nose with citrus-peel and resins, roasted malts, chocolate and licorice. The flavor is pretty much the same, roasted base with lots of hops up front, and a good bitterness taking you to the finish. No lack of malts either in the finish. Full-bodied and quite dry, yet with a sweetish impression. A lovely beer I wish was more readily available. 090912

Bottle at Københavnske Øldage 2009Totally black color. Nice American hops aroma, overall too aggressive roasted malt flavor, against the hops, even if it has a very smooth mouthfeel. Quite dry final, with ashes Not impressive.

Black with a lasting tan head. Delicious hop aroma, signature Columbus floral and pine notes, along with roasted aromas, certainly not unlike Nøgne Øs Imperial Stout. Flavoour is somewhat sweet, dark chocolate and hops dominate. Delicious hoppy bitter finish.
cant decide if it wants to be a hoppy brew or a heavy stout, falls somewhere in between...

A jet black pour with a brown head - looks like a proper imperial stout. Aroma is all hops though, perhaps a hint of roast malt. The flavor is an odd mixing of the two styles - hop bitterness and flavor, but mostly burnt notes from the roast barley. Mouthfeel is a little thinner than Id expect from such a dark beer. An interesting style - they took a very dark stout, and added a shitload of hops.

From Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, DK.
Bottled, 300609.
Black with small head. Aroma of coffee and pine. Flavor is roasted malt with fruit and hop spices
Bottle. Pitch black with a bubbly lasting and lacing cappucino coloured head. Aromas of pine, roasted malt and coffee. Flavour of bitter hops, resin, hard roasted malt and licorice.

500ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)
Black, small head. Dry aroma - ashy. Lively carbonation. Body quite full, but very burnt and dry. And yes, ashy. Hops are pleasant though. Finish is ashy. Went a bit over-the-top with the roasting, alas. If that was reined back a bit, this would be a fairly tasty beer. Swapped half of it for half of a Samaels, and I think I got the better part of that deal.

19-06-2009.
Bottle @home.
Wonderfull beer.
Clearly an IPA nose, but taste is stout with strong IPA bitterness, but it all blends in so naturally(!).
Very dark with a huge brown head. Very complex with some minty flavors and then the wonderfull long bitter finish. MORE!
Nice light malt and hop aroma. Black color with a brown head. Nice full chocolate and liquorice body with a dry hop finish. Nice

bottle 500 ml shared at Pikkulintu Helsinki #407 EXP 280114. Murky black creamy thick beige head lacing. Strong roasted almost burnt malts ashy dry. Very strong after kick of hops. I almost felt like bite again a chunky hop pellet. Oh no this I want more so beer geek I am- No daily basis but some times.
Black of color with a nice brown head. An aroma of liqurice, hop, coffe and dry. A flavor of liqurice, hops, choclate, coffee, bitter and dusty.

(Bottle - batch 407 - at Pikkulintu, Helsinki, on 2009-06-10) Dark and thick. Large tan coloured head with lot of small bubbles. Hops and roastedness in aroma. Black with amedium beige head. Aroma had burned malt, chocolate and hoppy notes. Flavour was quite hoppy with burned malt, dark bitter chocolate.finished bitter.

(Bottled) Very dark brown with a medium-large, light brown head. Aroma of roasted, lightly burned malt, faint oatmeal sourness, hints of licorice.
